header.title: BABYLONIAN MAGIC AND SORCERY: Being 'The Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand.'
header.category: Western Esotericism, Assyriology, Mesopotamian Magic, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: This work aims to publish, transliterate, and translate a complete group of cuneiform tablets from the British Museum's Kuyunjik Collection, titled 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand.' These texts elucidate the devotional and magical practices of ancient Babylonia and Assyria, providing a systematic foundation for the scientific study of their religious and magical traditions, emphasizing the operative mechanics of divine invocation and ritual efficacy.

structure_content.summary: The preface introduces the book's primary objective: to present cuneiform texts of Babylonian and Assyrian prayers and incantations, alongside transliterations, translations, and a vocabulary. It details the provenance of these tablets from the British Museum's Kuyunjik Collection, notes their editing by Ashurbanipal's scribes, and highlights their likely Babylonian origins. The core concept of 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand' as a title signifying divine invocation is introduced.

The introduction provides extensive context on the tablets, including their physical characteristics, dimensions, and writing styles. It categorizes the 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand' as a distinct class of religious texts used in private worship, often accompanied by elaborate ceremonial directions. Detailed analysis of textual arrangement, including catch-lines, duplicates, and colophons, reveals a complex history of editing and rearrangement. Key magical formulas, such as the 'eclipse formula,' and the metrical structures of the prayers are explored, alongside a wide array of prescribed ritual actions and offerings.

This section serves as an organizational guide, categorizing the included tablets based on the deities to whom the prayers are addressed. Categories include groups of deities, individual gods (Marduk, Bîl, Rammân, Nabû, Sin, Nirgal), individual goddesses (Ša-la, Ištar, Tašmîtu, Mî-mî, Bîlit), deities whose names are not preserved, astral deities (Muštabarrû-mûtânu, Mul-mul, Kak-si-di, Sibziana), and prayers specifically against the evils associated with lunar eclipses.

This forms the bulk of the book, presenting each numbered tablet with its cuneiform text, followed by a precise transliteration into Latin characters, an English translation, and comprehensive philological notes. The content covers prayers, incantations, and detailed instructions for accompanying ceremonies, allowing for a deep dive into the practical application and linguistic nuances of Babylonian-Assyrian magic. Editorial conventions for restoring broken texts and noting variant readings are also outlined.

A detailed glossary of Sumero-Akkadian terms and ideograms found in the texts, providing their definitions and references to specific line numbers where they appear. This section is critical for philological understanding and for accurate interpretation of the magical formulae and ritual instructions.

The appendixes provide supplementary information, including indexes for proper names (deities, individuals), numerals, and words or ideographs of uncertain reading. The indexes further categorize tablets by number and registration, facilitating cross-referencing and comprehensive study of the texts and their duplicates.

This concluding section contains photographic plates or hand-drawn facsimiles of the original cuneiform tablets. These visual representations are crucial for scholars and practitioners to directly engage with the ancient script and verify the transliterations and translations provided, offering an authentic glimpse into the source material.

key_concepts.term: Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand (nis qâti)
key_concepts.definition: A distinct class of Babylonian and Assyrian magical and devotional texts, frequently identified by specific colophon-lines and often accompanied by detailed ritual instructions. The title refers to the symbolic gesture of raising the hands during divine invocation, signifying a plea or offering.

A recurring textual formula within the prayers, explicitly stating that the ritual is performed on the occasion of a lunar eclipse ('ina lumun iluatali ilu Sin sa ina arhi pulâni ûmi pulâni išakna(na)'). This formula signifies a specific magical purpose: to avert the malevolent influences or portents associated with such celestial events.

A standardized line found at the conclusion of many tablets in this collection, typically written in Sumero-Akkadian. It serves to identify the text type (e.g., INIM.INIM.MA ŠU IL.LA, 'Words of the Raising of the Hand'), often names the specific deity addressed, and sometimes indicates the tablet's numerical position within a larger series or its origin.

Prescriptive instructions accompanying the prayers, usually introduced by 'îpuš annam' ('Do the following'). These directions detail the necessary ritual components, including specific offerings (incense, libations, plants, animal parts, precious stones), precise actions (sprinkling, anointing, casting objects, knotting cords), and optimal timing (e.g., 'at night,' 'on a favorable day,' 'during a certain phase of the moon,' 'when the wind is in a certain quarter').

The designated priest or ritual specialist responsible for reciting the incantations and executing the prescribed ceremonies. The mašmašu acts on behalf of the suppliant, particularly in contexts of healing, purification, or divine intercession, ensuring the correct and efficacious performance of the magical rite.

A significant archaeological assemblage of cuneiform tablets, primarily from Ashurbanipal's royal library at Nineveh, housed in the British Museum. This collection forms the primary source material for King's study, containing a vast array of literary, administrative, and magical texts, including the 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand'.

practical_system.description: The book delineates a practical system of Babylonian and Assyrian ceremonial magic focused on intercession, purification, healing, and protection against malevolent forces and unfavorable omens. The system's efficacy is contingent upon the scrupulous adherence to prescribed ritual actions and the accurate recitation of specific incantations and prayers. It integrates spiritual supplication with material offerings and symbolic magical acts, often facilitated by a mašmašu priest.
tools: Inscribed Clay Tablets: The primary medium containing the prayers, incantations, and ritual instructions.
Censer (SA.NA): A specialized vessel for burning incense as an offering.
Libation Vessel (KAS.SAG): A container for liquid offerings such as water, mead, or wine.
Oil Vessel: Used for storing and dispensing oils for anointing and ritual casting.
Specific Plants and Woods: Employed for symbolic offerings, purification, or as components in magical formulas (e.g., mastakal-plant, urqarinnu-wood, binu-wood).
Knotted Cord (riksu): A ritual tool used in binding or loosening spells, often mentioned with instructions for its manipulation.
Divine Images/Statues: Representations of gods and goddesses placed on altars, before which offerings are made and prayers are recited.
rituals: Invocation: Raising the hand (nis qâti) as a fundamental gesture of divine appeal.

Offerings: Presenting various materials including incense (SA.NA), drink-offerings (KAS.SAG), water, honey, butter, specific plants (mastakal-plant, urqarinnu-wood, binu-wood, uṣuru-wood), animal parts (flesh), and precious items (gold, lapis-lazuli, alabaster).
Anointing: Application of oil to oneself, cultic objects, or divine images.

Symbolic Actions: Sprinkling green boughs with pure water, casting specific seeds or plaster fragments into oil, and binding or loosening knotted cords (riksu tapatar) to symbolize magical control or release.
Recitation: Chanting incantations, often repeated multiple times (e.g., 'three times,' 'seven times'), directed towards divine images or specific astrological configurations.
Timing: Performing rituals during astrologically significant periods such as night, favorable days, specific phases of the moon, or under particular wind conditions.
Purification: Rites intended to cleanse the suppliant from sin, disease, and evil influences.
Divine Intercession: Direct appeals to deities to mediate with other gods, return favor after divine anger, or grant prophetic dreams and visions.

relevant_quotes.text: The prayers and formulae inscribed on the tablets, which bore the title of 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand,' were drawn up for use in the private worship, either of the king himself, or of certain of his subjects.

The title was appended to each prayer as a colophon-line together with the name of the deity to whom the prayer was addressed; it is always found following the composition, and is enclosed within two lines ruled on the clay by the scribe.

In the evil of an eclipse of the Moon which in such and such a month on such and such a day has taken place, In the evil of the powers, of the portents, evil and not good which are in my palace and my land, The great gods beseech thee and thou givest counsel!

The 'Prayers of the Lifting of the Hand' are frequently accompanied by directions for the performance of ceremonies and the observance of certain rites. The paragraphs containing these directions are separated from the incantations by lines ruled on the clay by the scribe and they generally commence with the words ipus annam 'Do the following'.

It was necessary therefore to arrange them for publication on some other principle, and the plan adopted has been to classify them according to the deities to whom the prayers and incantations are addressed.

critical_analysis.relevance: King's 'Babylonian Magic and Sorcery' is a cornerstone for the study of Mesopotamian ritual magic. It moves beyond mere textual collection by providing meticulous philological analysis, rendering complex cuneiform texts accessible. For Western Esotericism and Occultism, this work is invaluable as it presents primary source material detailing operative magical systems, influencing later grimoire traditions and modern reconstructive magical practices. It demonstrates the sophisticated integration of spiritual devotion with practical ritual actions, emphasizing the efficacy of precise performance and invocation. The analysis of catch-lines and editorial processes offers insights into the transmission and adaptation of magical lore, a critical aspect of grimoire studies. Its detailed vocabulary further enhances understanding of ancient magical terminology.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book is essential for Assyriologists, academic scholars specializing in ancient Near Eastern religions and magic, and historians of religion. It is also a critical resource for occultists, ceremonial magicians, and practitioners of reconstructive magic who seek to understand and potentially implement historical Babylonian-Assyrian magical systems. Researchers interested in the historical development of grimoire traditions and the interplay between theology and ritual practice will find it highly relevant.
